Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Machining-Induced Influences to Ultra-Fine Grained Pure Titanium for Biomedical Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research award supports fundamental research on machining of ultra-fine grained pure titanium for biomedical applications. The research will test the hypothesis that machining induces microstructure changes in severe plastic deformation-processed ultra-fine grained metals, which affects their functionality and cell-material interaction performance. Specifically, key research activities include fabricating bulk ultra-fine grained titanium using equal channel angular extrusion, characterizing the machining-induced microstructure change and functionality variation in terms of grain size, dislocation density, residual stress, and corrosion behavior, and investigating machining-induced cell-material interaction alterations in terms of osteoblast cell adhesion and proliferation. Ultra-fine grained titanium bars will be studied because of titanium's promising use for medical implants and prosthetics.

Research results will provide knowledge and understanding of machining-induced material property variations and functionality alterations of severe plastic deformation-processed bulk ultra-fine grained titanium. The methodology will contribute to the adoption of ultra-fine grained metals in the healthcare industry requiring high strength and corrosion resistance and the automobile industry requiring high strength-to-weight ratios. This collaborative research project features a unique collaboration among materials processing, machining, and biomedical manufacturing researchers. The research activities will promote advanced manufacturing for healthcare applications as well as disciplinary education in materials, materials processing, and manufacturing through curriculum development. The research will also positively impact the participation of diverse groups and promotion of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics activities at the University of Florida, Texas A&M, and Georgia Tech.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to improve the fundamental understanding of an integrated manufacturing approach for ultra-fine-grained titanium (UFG Ti). A severe plastic deformation (SPD) process, specially referred to as the equal channel angular extrusion (ECAE), and machining process were employed in this integrated approach. The ultra-fine-grained titanium has demonstrated superior mechanical strength and high biocompatibility with human tissue. Therefore, it has a great potential to replace the commonly used Ti-6AL-4V in the medical implant field. In this collaborative research project, the fundamental understanding in machining SPD-processed UFG Ti has been improved with analytical and experimental studies of the machining process. The material constitutive relation was investigated in the context of the Johnson-Cook model (J-C) model, which describes the materials flow stress under various strain, strain rate, and temperature conditions. The Johnson-Cook model has been widely used in the predictive modeling of machining force, temperature, and residual stress because of its effectiveness, simplicity, and ease-of-use. The machining force, temperature distribution, and residual stress were investigated with physics-based analytical models and the J-C relationship in this study.

The constitutive relation of UFG Ti was not available in the literature, but was needed for the machining prediction. In the past, experimental approaches, numerical analyses, and analytical approaches were developed to determine the J-C model constants but the associated disadvantages including high experimental involvedness, low computational efficiency, and high mathematical complexity, rendered the determination of J-C constants difficult and challenging. In this project, an experimental study was performed with machining tests for UFG Ti in orthogonal cutting configuration and in situ measurements of machining force and temperature distribution; subsequently, an inverse determination methodology was been developed for identifying the J-C model constants using a modified chip formation model. An archival journal paper has been published for the proposed determination methodology. An improved inverse determination methodology has been developed for identifying J-C model constants using the modified chip formation model and an iterative gradient search method based on the Kalman Filter algorithm. An improvement in computational efficiency was observed, and the methodology and results were reported in a separate journal publication.

Physics-based analytical models were subsequently developed and used to predict forces and temperature distribution in the machining of UFG Ti. The predictions were validated by experimental measurements with good agreements, which also suggested the validity of the determined J-C model constants of UFG Ti. Another original temperature model was developed to predict temperature distributions in machining, specifically the average temperature in the primary shear zone (PSZ) and the temperature in the secondary shear zone (the tool-chip interface or SSZ), using materials constitutive modeling and machining process mechanics. The temperatures in the PSZ and the SSZ can be utilized to further predict machining forces, residual stress, and tool wear.

The developed model has the advantages of less mathematical complexity, less experimental intricacy, and high computational efficiency. The proposed physics-based analysis and the determination of UFG Ti constitutive behaviors can be utilized to further investigate processing technology for UFG Ti, such as the integration and optimization of SPD and machining processes and the manufactured part quality. The published results will be accessible and beneficial to professionals, scholars, and researchers who work in the related areas.


Last Modified: 06/13/2018
Modified by: Steven Y Liang
